article: What Is Devotion in Magic: The Gathering?
intro: First introduced in the Theros block, devotion is one of the most unique and enjoyable mechanics in Magic: The Gathering. The mechanic rewards you for playing a lot of permanents in the same color, which makes it fun to brew with if you love building mono-colored decks. In this article, we’ll break down what devotion is, how it works, and what the most popular devotion cards (and decks) are.

steps.title: Devotion counts the number of pips in a given color on the board.
steps.subtitle: In MTG, a pip refers to a single instance of a colored mana in a card’s mana cost. Devotion is a mechanic that cares about the total number of pips in a certain color on the board. Notably, it is  counting pips—not colorless mana. Here is an example:

Next turn, you play a . It has 3 green pips so your devotion to green is now 4.
The next turn, you play a  for four mana where X is 2. Since there are no colored pips in Walking Ballista’s mana cost, it does nothing to change your devotion.
Next turn, you play a . The 1 colorless mana doesn’t count, but it increases your white  green devotion with the 3 hybrid mana. Now, your devotion to white is 3 and your devotion to green is 7.

steps.title: Devotion was first introduced with the Theros block.
steps.subtitle: Theros was a Greek mythology-inspired set released in 2013. The idea behind the mechanic was that the Gods in Theros grew more powerful based on the number of followers they had (as represented by the mana pips on the field).
sub-points: Each color in the original Theros block had a dedicated God: Heliod, God of the Sun (white), Thassa, God of the Sea (blue), Erebos, God of the Dead (black), Purphoros, God of the Forge (red), and Nylea, God of the Hunt (green). When your devotion to that god’s color reached 5, they’d “return” to battle as a creature.

Devotion is identical mechanically to chroma, a mechanic introduced in the Evertide set in 2008. Chroma wasn’t popular because it didn’t have any good cards and the flavor didn’t quite make sense, but devotion has turned into one of the more popular mechanics in the game.

Devotion is a unique mechanic because it doesn’t actually do anything on its own. It has no triggers, doesn’t use the stack, and can’t be activated. There are cards with abilities that care about devotion, but devotion itself is just counting pips.

points.name: Do cards with devotion count themselves?

steps.title: Yes, as soon as a card enters the battlefield, it counts.
steps.subtitle: If a card is on the field, it counts towards your devotion. Just know, devotion does not care about the graveyard, the stack, exile, or your hand. It is  counting the cards on the battlefield.
sub-points: So, if you’ve got a  on the field and then you play an , the devotion count is 1 when the Eidolon is on the stack, but 3 the exact moment the Eidolon enters the battlefield.

points.name: Do copies of cards add to devotion?

steps.title: Yes, cards that copy other cards also copy mana costs.
steps.subtitle: If a card duplicates another card or creates a copy of another card, the mana cost is recreated as well. Take a look at , as an example. If Pack Rat made two copies of itself on an empty board, your devotion to black would be 3.
sub-points: Cards that clone other cards also copy their mana cost. So, let’s say you cast  and you copy your opponent’s . The Image becomes a copy and now you have 3 devotion to white and 3 devotion to red from the Reckoner. You have zero devotion to blue.

steps.title: If it’s not a token of a specific card, no—tokens have no mana cost.
steps.subtitle: A token of a specific card on the battlefield will always copy its mana cost. However, if it’s a token creature that isn’t copying something specific, it has no devotion. So, a card like  creates three 1/1 spirit tokens with flying and those tokens add nothing to devotion.
sub-points: The same would apply for tokens created by planeswalkers, tokens generated by sorceries and instants, and tokens created by activated abilities that don’t clone specific cards.

points.name: How do alternate costs work with devotion?

steps.title: Devotion only cares about the mana cost at the top.
steps.subtitle: Take a look at . While you could cast it for WUBRG, you will only get 2 devotion to black once it hits the board. Any alternative costs for creatures are irrelevant—devotion is exclusively checking the mana value located next to the name of the card at the top.
sub-points: For cards with mutation, devotion only counts the card on top of the mutation stack.
Dual-faced cards (like ) only contribute to devotion if there’s a mana cost on the front.

The one exception to the “top line only” rule is with prototype. If you cast a card with prototype for its alternate cost, that becomes the mana cost of the card. So, if you cast [Arcane Proxy] for its prototype cost, your devotion to blue is 2.

points.name: How does hybrid mana work with devotion?

steps.title: Hybrid pips give devotion to all represented colors.
steps.subtitle: A card like  has a hybrid mana in its converted mana cost—it can be cast for 1 green mana or 1 white mana. On the battlefield, you get devotion for both.
sub-points: Remember, colorless mana does not contribute to devotion. A card like  grants devotion of 2 blue and 2 white, but that 1 colorless mana does nothing.

steps.title: Any creature or spell with an X in the cost.
steps.subtitle: Devotion decks are notorious for generating a frankly ridiculous amount of mana, so anything you can sink your mana into is an extremely attractive inclusion.  becomes a serious threat.  can win the game out of nowhere. If it’s got an X in the casting cost, devotion can make it work.
sub-points: Alongside Nykthos, cards like  and  help churn out silly amounts of mana.
This is part of why devotion is such a popular mechanic from brewers. You can basically convert entire shells and ideas into devotion decks just based on the amount of mana you can generate.
